s.text: (Today's Papers can barely wait for the Brill's Content analysis of these analyses of that analysis.)
One U.S. official working on the international aid response is quoted by the paper saying, "You have areas where the mud is more than one story deep and the bodies will never be recovered.

The New York Times puts Venezuela inside (although it fronts a picture of troops maintaining order there in the aftermath) and goes instead with the New York state court ruling that the Giuliani administration's aggressive strategy for restricting the number of X-rated bookstores and movie theaters in the Big Apple was based on an overly broad definition of an adult-oriented business.

The New York Times puts Venezuela inside (although it fronts a picture of troops maintaining order there in the aftermath) and goes instead with the New York state court ruling that the Giuliani administration's aggressive strategy for restricting the number of X-rated bookstores and movie theaters in the Big Apple was based on an overly broad definition of an adult-oriented business.

The New York Times puts Venezuela inside (although it fronts a picture of troops maintaining order there in the aftermath) and goes instead with the New York state court ruling that the Giuliani administration's aggressive strategy for restricting the number of X-rated bookstores and movie theaters in the Big Apple was based on an overly broad definition of an adult-oriented business.
The papers report that hardest hit in Venezuela is the coastal state of Vargas, which has been transformed, says the LAT , into "a landscape of destruction filled with the stench of death."

The WP and LAT off-lead, and the NYT goes above the fold with yesterday's decision by the Vermont Supreme Court that gay and lesbian couples are entitled to the same legal benefits and protections enjoyed by heterosexual married couples.

The WP and LAT off-lead, and the NYT goes above the fold with yesterday's decision by the Vermont Supreme Court that gay and lesbian couples are entitled to the same legal benefits and protections enjoyed by heterosexual married couples.

The WP and LAT off-lead, and the NYT goes above the fold with yesterday's decision by the Vermont Supreme Court that gay and lesbian couples are entitled to the same legal benefits and protections enjoyed by heterosexual married couples.

The court left it up to the legislature to decide whether this equal entitlement can best be achieved via legalizing gay marriage or, alternatively, by codifying the rights and benefits of domestic partners.
